summary: a system based on a Sendai virus minigenome produced heterologous viral glycoproteins in the allantoic cavity of embryonated eggs. the first step was rescuing in cell cultures Sendai virus minigenomes encoding the proteins of interest, with the helper virus. the second step was propagating such recombinant defective viruses, together with the helper virus, in the allantoic cavity of embryonated eggs. a repertoire of animal viruses has been grown in embryonated chicken eggs since the early 1930's. eggs have the appealing properties of low cost and ease of manipulation for large-scale production of viruses and recombinant proteins. cDNA cloning and rescue of recombinant paramyxoviruses still entails laborious steps. paramyxovirus minigenomes obtained by cDNA cloning can be amplified in transfected cells either expressing a minimal set of complementing viral proteins or superinfected with a wild type homologous helper virus. a seV minigenome seemed attractive and versatile vector for the expression of foreign proteins in chicken eggs. rVV expressing an anchorless form of HMPV/F protein has been made. cDNA SeV minigenome encodes an HA tagged SeV matrix protein
